title: Training and Body Composition
content: You would expect an athlete going from age 19 to 23 to 27 would put on muscle and gain weight, but Apolo actually continually got leaner and leaner (while maintaining strength). In 2002, training was about power, ballistics, strength, and speed. He weighed 165 lbs and had an exceptional ability to recover quickly. He could leg press 1,500 lbs and his vertical was 36 inches. By 2006, he weighed 155 lbs but could still leg press the same weight. He was significantly leaner. In 2010, he weighed 143 lbs and could leg press nearly 2,000 lbs. He had less ballistic power and stopped doing Olympic lifts. He did a lot of weighted plyometrics and spent much of the time purposefully atrophying his upper body.

title: Mental Component of Sports
content: The mental component of the sport was always to me the most fascinating and the most underutilized in every aspect. Early on he started working with a young sport psychologist (David Creswell) and together they worked on Meditation and breathing exercises, Positive self-talk, Manifesting what you want through visualization. He would train until he puked for no other reason than to try to develop the mental toughness and fortitude.

title: Preparing for the World Stage
content: In preparation for the 1997 World Team trials to make the 1997 World Team, Apolo began putting in extra work in the weight room. He saw massive gains with relatively little effort and ended up winning the trials and qualifying for the World Team. At age 14, he was competing against grown men, placed 19th at the 1997 Speed Skating World Cup, and after witnessing the style and attitudes of the foreign teams (Korea, China) came away with the impression that the US was way behind the times in terms of the training and skating strategy.

title: Self-Sabotage and Training
content: With the approaching Olympic trials, Apolo fell back into old habits in Seattle, stopped training, ate crappy food, and lost interest in putting in the effort. Apolo was just going through the motions in his training. Barely made the cut for a chance just to compete in the Olympic trials. At the Olympic Trials, he didn’t get anywhere close to qualifying for the Olympics.

title: Making a Commitment and Training
content: After about nine days of contemplation and soul searching, Apolo made the decision to commit to speed skating. Over the next few months he trained in solitude in his father’s basement, didn’t talk to anyone, just trained and studied. When he got back to the training center in Colorado Springs, he was by far the best skater in the national team program.

title: Training with Korean Skaters
content: In 2007, Apolo realized that to stay competitive he had to go into the Lion’s Den and train with the best skaters in the world, the South Koreans. Apolo lived and trained in South Korea in 2007, during his time there he was struck by the following characteristics of the skaters: Commitment to perfection in their technique and preparation, Efficiency in which they move on the ice which made their physical strength less important, Uniformity of the team who all seemed to skate the same.

title: Mental Health and Athletic Performance
content: “I was driven a lot by my pure fear that the guys on the other side of the world were better, more prepared, younger, more talented, and genetically-gifted. . .and the only way I knew was just to be tougher mentally and to be able to withstand a pain threshold that they wouldn’t even dare step into”. Despite having severe food poisoning, he won the competition, and more importantly, he won the respect of the South Korean citizens.

title: Ideal Body Composition for Short-Track Skating
content: The perfect short-track body composition includes a pelvis tilted forward, a rounded lower back, a shorter torso, long legs, a thinner frame naturally, minimal upper body weight, and a strong lower body. Strength to weight ratio is important. South Koreans seemed to have this naturally. Apolo did not have this naturally, nor did the way he skated feel natural, had to force it and only after years of training was it automatic.

title: Mental Health Challenges Post-Retirement
content: The struggle many athletes face after retirement includes difficulty in applying their greatness in sport to their next chapter in life and feeling like they’ve lost their sense of purpose and belonging. It was incredibly difficult for former Olympians who dedicated the last 4,8, 12+ years towards learning a skill that doesn’t translate to real life. The lack of a clear goal and structure is hard because it’s all you’ve known for years. “It gets dark” when their sense of purpose and belonging go away.

title: Training and Mental Fortitude
content: After his suboptimal performance at the world championship in 2009, he checked himself into the Colorado Springs training center and just trained in solitude. His plan was to improve cadence, lower body weight, maintain strength, and get in the best aerobic shape in his life. This included long bike rides, inline skates, running, treadmill, and Stairmaster. He also trained on the Manitou Incline in Colorado Springs multiple times per week in a 40 lb weighted vest.

title: Health Goals for the Future
content: In 10 years, he wants to be healthy, first and foremost. He also wants to increase relationships with family and friends. He wants to give back to the youth and help kids understand the importance of sports and the amazing life lessons of commitment, dedication, discipline that you can learn.

title: Pursuit of Perfection and Flow States
content: Apolo says some of his favorite moments were when he entered a flow state. “Felt like Neo from the Matrix”. Flow is an addictive feeling even for non-athletes, doctors, writer, singer, etc. Apolo on finding flow: “I’m convinced that you have to care enough about the outcome for you to get in that state. There has to be some form of consequence, maybe not physical or immediate danger, but psychologically to impact you to almost force yourself into that realm.”
